results.title: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne's Art Trams
results.creator_credit: Michael Buckley, National Heart Foundation of Australia. Victorian Division and Arts Victoria
results.brief_description: Trams have always been a feature of Melbourne life and they have now been transformed into moving art galleries. Melbourne’s Transporting Art Project involves a new series of decorated trams. Several of the artists discuss their reasons for taking part in the scheme, the themes behind their work and the unusual medium. Artists include Aleks Danko, Philip Faulks, Lin Onus, Terry Matassoni, Jenny Watson and Brett Colquhoun.
results.title_for_label: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne’s Art Trams
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Buckley, National Heart Foundation of Australia. Victorian Division and Arts Victoria

results.title: Whole School Planning
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Institute of Educational Administration
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Case studies in effective schooling”.
Case studies in effective schooling presents first hand accounts of how individual schools have improved their effectiveness. The first episode, “Whole school planning” looks at planning as a manageable series of arrangements designed to involve all interested parties and to make the best use of limited resources. Deer Park Secondary College features in this case study.

results.title: Cooee
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In 1915, the Australian Land Army marched on the Cooee trail from the mid-western farming town of Gilgandra to Sydney, gathering volunteer troops for the Dardanelles on the way. In 1987, a new band of “Cooees” set off to re-enact the march. The film’s production crew were involved from the march’s planning stage. This record of the re-enactment covering the 550 km from Gilgandra to the Sydney Town Hall not only provides a portrait of the individuals involved but also gives a glimpse of the mood and attitudes of rural Australia, 1987.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Chase, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia

results.title: Plagued. Episodes 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Edward Goldwyn, Janet Bell, Deanne Edwards, Channel Four, Goldwyn Associates and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Invisible armies examines infectious diseases and how they have been carried around the world as cultures come into contact with each other, and also how some previously eliminated diseases, such as measles and TB, are making a comeback in the western world because of carelessness about immunisation programs. Diseases discussed include syphilis, malaria and smallpox. “Will we ever learn?” Never before have we had such powerful weapons against disease but the tendency to depend on them too much has led to a philosophy of cure rather than prevention. The program looks at AIDS, syphilis and diseases associated with tobacco use and salt. Norman Swan wrote and narrates this thought provoking series, which contends that the real causes of epidemics are social forces.

results.title: Rolf Harris' water safety
results.creator_credit: Jessica Skippon and Rolf Harris Video Productions
results.brief_description: A water safety program featuring Rolf Harris and four children, aimed at children up to about twelve years of age. The tape is divided into three sections. 1. Spot the danger (15 mins.) 2. Boating and falling into cold water (17 mins.) 3. Reach throw wade row and rescue breathing (24 mins.)

results.title: Admission impossible
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Chris Oliver and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The very first Act passed by Australia’s first parliament was a law to exclude non-white races from Australia. “Admission impossible” is the true story of the behind-the-scenes political forces and propaganda that created the infamous White Australia Policy which was enforced until 1972. Eyewitness accounts and recently discovered confidential documents reveal how immigration officers carried out racial selectivity to discriminate against Asians, Jews and non-European applicants. The last part of the program discusses the impact the Vietnam War had on the reversal of this policy.

results.title: La Stupenda: a portrait of Dame Joan Sutherland
results.creator_credit: Derek Bailey, Brian Adams and Landseer Film and Television Productions
results.brief_description: A celebration of the life and career of Australia’s most famous opera star, Dame Joan Sutherland, culminating in her farewell performances in Sydney and London in 1990. Sutherland’s career spanned more than forty years. “La Stupenda” provides an overview of the highlights of her career.
